KElbowVisualizer.name: K-Elbow Visualizer
KElbowVisualizer.description: Plots the distortion score (within-cluster sum of squared distances) against different values of K. Helps identify the 'elbow' point where adding more clusters yields diminishing returns.
KElbowVisualizer.interpretation: Look for the 'elbow' - where the curve bends sharply and starts to flatten. Before the elbow, adding clusters significantly reduces distortion. After it, improvements are marginal.
KElbowVisualizer.ecci_context: For customer segmentation, the elbow method helps find the natural number of customer groups. Too few clusters oversimplify behavior patterns; too many create noise and marketing complexity.
KElbowVisualizer.when_to_use: Use when choosing the number of clusters for KMeans. Essential first step before analyzing cluster quality with other visualizers.
KElbowVisualizer.parameters: `k`: Range of K values to test, `metric`: distortion (default), silhouette, calinski_harabasz

SilhouetteVisualizer.name: Silhouette Visualizer
SilhouetteVisualizer.description: Shows silhouette coefficients for each sample, grouped by cluster. Each cluster appears as a 'knife shape' where width indicates cluster size and coefficient indicates sample fit quality.
SilhouetteVisualizer.interpretation: Uniform knife shapes of similar width indicate well-balanced clusters. Samples with negative silhouette scores may be misassigned. Wide variation within a cluster suggests internal heterogeneity.
SilhouetteVisualizer.ecci_context: Reveals which customer segments are well-defined vs. ambiguous. Negative scores indicate customers that might fit better in other segments - potential for re-assignment or finer segmentation.
SilhouetteVisualizer.when_to_use: Use after KMeans training to validate cluster quality. Essential for understanding how well samples fit their assigned clusters.
SilhouetteVisualizer.parameters: `colors`: Color palette for clusters, `ax`: Matplotlib axes object

InterclusterDistance.name: Intercluster Distance Map
InterclusterDistance.description: A 2D embedding showing cluster centers as circles. Circle size represents cluster membership count, and positions show relative distances between cluster centers.
InterclusterDistance.interpretation: Well-separated circles indicate distinct clusters. Overlapping or very close circles suggest similar clusters that might be merged. Large circles are dominant segments.
InterclusterDistance.ecci_context: Visualizes how distinct customer segments are from each other. Overlapping clusters might indicate similar browsing/purchase patterns that could be combined for simpler marketing.
InterclusterDistance.when_to_use: Use to understand cluster relationships and whether clusters represent truly distinct customer behaviors or could be consolidated.
InterclusterDistance.parameters: `embedding`: Dimensionality reduction method (MDS, TSNE), `legend`: Show cluster legends

Rank1D.name: Rank 1D (Feature Ranking)
Rank1D.description: Ranks individual features using a statistical test. By default uses Shapiro-Wilk test to measure how normally distributed each feature is.
Rank1D.interpretation: Higher scores indicate features that deviate more from normal distribution. Features with non-normal distributions might benefit from transformation or may indicate interesting patterns.
Rank1D.ecci_context: Identifies which customer features have unusual distributions. For example, price or time_on_page might be heavily skewed, indicating different customer types (browsers vs. buyers).
Rank1D.when_to_use: Use during feature engineering to understand individual feature characteristics. Helps identify features that might need transformation (log, sqrt, etc.).
Rank1D.parameters: `algorithm`: Ranking algorithm (shapiro, variance), `orient`: Horizontal or vertical bars

Rank2D.name: Rank 2D (Feature Correlation Matrix)
Rank2D.description: A heatmap showing pairwise relationships between features. Supports Pearson correlation, Spearman rank correlation, covariance, and Kendall tau.
Rank2D.interpretation: Red = positive correlation, Blue = negative correlation, White = no correlation. Look for: (1) highly correlated feature pairs (redundancy), (2) unexpected correlations that might indicate feature interactions.
Rank2D.ecci_context: Identify redundant features (e.g., price and quantity might correlate). Check if derived features (hour, day) correlate with event_type. Unusual correlations might reveal customer behavior patterns.
Rank2D.when_to_use: Use for multicollinearity detection before clustering. Helps select features and understand feature relationships.
Rank2D.parameters: `algorithm`: Correlation method (pearson, spearman, covariance, kendalltau), `colormap`: Color scheme

PCA.name: PCA (Principal Component Analysis)
PCA.description: Projects high-dimensional data onto 2 principal components for visualization. Each point is a customer interaction, colored by cluster assignment.
PCA.interpretation: If clusters form visually distinct groups, the clustering captures meaningful variance. Overlapping clusters indicate features may not fully separate customer behaviors.
PCA.ecci_context: Shows whether customer segments have fundamentally different feature patterns. Clear separation = distinct customer types. Heavy overlap = subtle differences requiring more features or different algorithms.
PCA.when_to_use: Use as a quick sanity check for cluster separability. Fast to compute and gives immediate visual feedback on clustering quality.
PCA.parameters: `scale`: Standardize features before PCA, `projection`: Number of components (2 or 3), `classes`: Cluster names for legend

Manifold.name: Manifold (t-SNE/UMAP)
Manifold.description: Non-linear dimensionality reduction that preserves local structure. t-SNE is effective at revealing clusters that linear methods (PCA) might miss.
Manifold.interpretation: Points close together are similar in the original high-dimensional space. Look for: (1) distinct cluster islands, (2) sub-groups within clusters, (3) outliers far from any cluster.
Manifold.ecci_context: Can reveal **customer sub-segments** - different behavior patterns (heavy browsers, quick buyers, comparison shoppers) might form separate groups. More powerful than PCA but SLOW (30-120 seconds).
Manifold.when_to_use: Use for deep exploration of data structure when PCA doesn't show clear patterns. Run on sampled data first due to computational cost.
Manifold.parameters: `manifold`: Algorithm (tsne, umap, isomap, mds), `n_neighbors`: Neighborhood size, `random_state`: Reproducibility seed

ParallelCoordinates.name: Parallel Coordinates
ParallelCoordinates.description: Each feature is a vertical axis. Each customer interaction is a line connecting its values across all features. Lines are colored by cluster.
ParallelCoordinates.interpretation: Look for feature ranges where cluster lines separate. If lines from different clusters cross similarly, that feature doesn't help discrimination.
ParallelCoordinates.ecci_context: Identify **feature ranges that distinguish customer segments**: e.g., high time_on_page + low quantity = browsers, high quantity + Electronics = bulk buyers.
ParallelCoordinates.when_to_use: Use to understand multi-dimensional patterns and feature interactions. Best with normalized features and sampling (too many lines = visual noise).
ParallelCoordinates.parameters: `normalize`: Scaling method (minmax, standard), `sample`: Fraction of data to plot, `alpha`: Line transparency

RadViz.name: RadViz (Radial Visualization)
RadViz.description: Features are arranged as points on a circle. Each customer interaction is positioned based on its feature values - pulled toward features with high values.
RadViz.interpretation: If cluster points group in specific regions, those nearby features characterize that segment. Points near the center have balanced feature values.
RadViz.ecci_context: Quickly identifies which features 'pull' customer segments to specific regions. Good for discovering feature combinations that characterize segments (e.g., mobile users cluster near OS + browser).
RadViz.when_to_use: Use for quick visual cluster separability check. Works best with normalized features and moderate number of features (5-15).
RadViz.parameters: `alpha`: Point transparency, `classes`: Cluster names for legend

JointPlot.name: Joint Plot (2D Feature Correlation)
JointPlot.description: Scatter plot showing relationship between two features with marginal histograms. Includes correlation coefficient.
JointPlot.interpretation: The scatter plot shows feature co-occurrence patterns. Marginal histograms show individual distributions. Correlation coefficient quantifies linear relationship.
JointPlot.ecci_context: Explore specific feature pairs: e.g., price vs quantity (do high-value customers buy more?), time_on_page vs event_type (do browsers spend more time?).
JointPlot.when_to_use: Use for deep-dive into specific feature pairs after Rank2D identifies interesting correlations. Good for hypothesis testing about customer behavior.
JointPlot.parameters: `columns`: Two feature names to plot, `correlation`: Method (pearson, spearman), `kind`: Plot type (scatter, hex)

ClassBalance.name: Class Balance (Cluster Distribution)
ClassBalance.description: Bar chart showing the count (or proportion) of samples in each cluster. Shows how evenly distributed customers are across segments.
ClassBalance.interpretation: Equal-height bars = balanced clusters. Very unequal bars indicate dominant segments and rare customer types.
ClassBalance.ecci_context: **Critical for marketing resource allocation!** A cluster with 80% of customers needs different attention than one with 2%. Small clusters might be high-value niches or outliers to investigate.
ClassBalance.when_to_use: Always visualize first. Understanding cluster balance is fundamental to marketing strategy and resource allocation.
ClassBalance.parameters: `labels`: Cluster names for x-axis, `colors`: Bar colors per cluster

FeatureCorrelation.name: Feature Correlation (Mutual Information)
FeatureCorrelation.description: Bar chart showing correlation between each feature and the cluster assignment. Uses mutual information which captures non-linear relationships.
FeatureCorrelation.interpretation: Higher bars = stronger predictors of cluster assignment. Unlike Pearson correlation, mutual information captures any statistical dependency.
FeatureCorrelation.ecci_context: Identifies which features most strongly define customer segments. Top features should make business sense (event_type, product_category). Unexpected top features might indicate algorithmic quirks.
FeatureCorrelation.when_to_use: Use to understand what drives cluster separation. Features with near-zero mutual information might be removable without losing cluster quality.
FeatureCorrelation.parameters: `method`: mutual_info-classification, `labels`: Feature names, `sort`: Order by importance

FeatureCorrelation_Pearson.name: Feature Correlation (Pearson)
FeatureCorrelation_Pearson.description: Bar chart showing linear correlation between each feature and the cluster assignment. Faster than mutual information but only captures linear relationships.
FeatureCorrelation_Pearson.interpretation: Positive values = feature increases with cluster ID, Negative = decreases. Values near zero = no linear relationship (but non-linear relationship might exist).
FeatureCorrelation_Pearson.ecci_context: Quick linear analysis - which features linearly separate clusters? Compare with Mutual Information: features with low Pearson but high MI have non-linear relationships worth exploring.
FeatureCorrelation_Pearson.when_to_use: Use as a fast complement to Mutual Information. Useful when you suspect linear relationships or want quick feature screening.
FeatureCorrelation_Pearson.parameters: `method`: pearson, `labels`: Feature names, `sort`: Order by absolute correlation

BalancedBinningReference.name: Balanced Binning Reference
BalancedBinningReference.description: Histogram of a continuous feature with vertical lines showing optimal bin boundaries for balanced binning. Helps understand feature distributions.
BalancedBinningReference.interpretation: Shows feature distribution and suggested quantile-based bins. For continuous features, helps decide discretization strategies.
BalancedBinningReference.ecci_context: **Useful for price/time_on_page analysis.** Shows how these continuous features are distributed across customers. Can inform feature engineering (binning price into categories).
BalancedBinningReference.when_to_use: Use for continuous feature analysis when considering discretization. Helps understand continuous feature distributions.
BalancedBinningReference.parameters: `bins`: Number of bins to create, `target`: Target column name

FeatureImportances.name: Feature Importances
FeatureImportances.description: Horizontal bar chart ranking features by their importance in the model. For KMeans, this shows which features contribute most to cluster separation.
FeatureImportances.interpretation: Longer bars = more important features. The model relies more heavily on top features. Bottom features might be removable without losing cluster quality.
FeatureImportances.ecci_context: Reveals what KMeans learned: which features drive customer segmentation? Top features should align with business intuition (event_type, product_category). Unexpected rankings warrant investigation.
FeatureImportances.when_to_use: Use after training to interpret the model. Essential for model debugging, feature selection, and explaining segments to stakeholders.
FeatureImportances.parameters: `labels`: Feature names, `relative`: Show as percentage of max importance, `absolute`: Show raw importance values

CVScores.name: Cross-Validation Scores
CVScores.description: Bar chart showing model performance (silhouette score) across different cross-validation folds. Includes mean score and standard deviation.
CVScores.interpretation: Consistent bars = stable clustering. High variance across folds = model is sensitive to data split, suggesting overfitting or unstable clusters.
CVScores.ecci_context: Verifies cluster stability across different subsets of customers. High variance might mean segments aren't consistent across time periods or customer samples.
CVScores.when_to_use: Use to verify clustering stability and get confidence intervals on quality estimates. Essential before using segments for marketing.
CVScores.parameters: `cv`: Number of folds, `scoring`: Metric to evaluate (silhouette, calinski_harabasz)

ValidationCurve.name: Validation Curve
ValidationCurve.description: Shows how training and validation scores change as a hyperparameter varies. Helps identify optimal hyperparameter values and detect overfitting.
ValidationCurve.interpretation: Gap between train/test = overfitting. Both decreasing = underfitting. Find the hyperparameter value where test score peaks before train-test gap widens.
ValidationCurve.ecci_context: Tune KMeans parameters: n_clusters (primary), n_init (robustness), max_iter (convergence). Helps find the sweet spot for customer segmentation quality.
ValidationCurve.when_to_use: Use for hyperparameter tuning to find optimal complexity. Run for key hyperparameters like n_clusters.
ValidationCurve.parameters: `param_name`: Hyperparameter to tune, `param_range`: Values to test, `cv`: Cross-validation folds

LearningCurve.name: Learning Curve
LearningCurve.description: Shows how training and validation scores change as training set size increases. Helps diagnose if more data would improve the clustering.
LearningCurve.interpretation: Converging curves with gap = more data won't help much. Curves still far apart = more data would help improve cluster quality.
LearningCurve.ecci_context: Determines if collecting more customer interaction data would improve segmentation. If curves converge early, focus on feature engineering instead of data collection.
LearningCurve.when_to_use: Use when deciding whether to invest in data collection or model complexity. Helps set expectations for improvement potential.
LearningCurve.parameters: `train_sizes`: Fractions of training data to test, `cv`: Cross-validation folds, `scoring`: Metric to plot

RFECV.name: Recursive Feature Elimination (RFECV)
RFECV.description: Recursively removes least important features and tracks cross-validation score. Identifies the optimal number of features to use.
RFECV.interpretation: The curve shows score vs number of features. Peak indicates optimal feature count. Flat plateau means extra features don't hurt but don't help.
RFECV.ecci_context: Find minimal feature set for customer segmentation: fewer features = simpler segments to explain and act upon. Important for interpretable marketing segments.
RFECV.when_to_use: Use for feature selection when you want to simplify the model. Computationally expensive (VERY SLOW) - run on sampled data.
RFECV.parameters: `cv`: Cross-validation folds, `scoring`: Metric to optimize, `step`: Features to remove per iteration

DroppingCurve.name: Dropping Curve (Feature Robustness)
DroppingCurve.description: Shows how model performance changes when random subsets of features are used. Tests model robustness to missing features.
DroppingCurve.interpretation: Gradual decline = model is robust, features are redundant. Sharp decline = model relies heavily on specific features. Flat = many features are unnecessary.
DroppingCurve.ecci_context: Tests if customer segmentation is robust when some features are missing (common in production due to data quality issues). Identifies critical features that must be present.
DroppingCurve.when_to_use: Use to test production robustness and understand feature redundancy. Helps plan for graceful degradation when features are unavailable.
DroppingCurve.parameters: `feature_sizes`: Fractions of features to test, `cv`: Cross-validation folds, `random_state`: Reproducibility

sklearn:PartialDependenceDisplay.name: Partial Dependence (Sklearn)
sklearn:PartialDependenceDisplay.description: Shows how features influence the probability of belonging to a specific cluster, using pseudo-labels from clustering.
sklearn:PartialDependenceDisplay.interpretation: Curves highlight which feature values push events toward a cluster. Flat lines indicate low influence.
sklearn:PartialDependenceDisplay.ecci_context: Helps interpret cluster drivers: e.g., higher prices or longer sessions might increase the probability of a premium segment.
sklearn:PartialDependenceDisplay.when_to_use: Use for explaining cluster characteristics and validating that cluster drivers make sense.
sklearn:PartialDependenceDisplay.parameters: `features`: Feature names, `target`: Cluster index, `grid_resolution`: Curve detail

sklearn:LearningCurveDisplay.name: Learning Curve (Sklearn)
sklearn:LearningCurveDisplay.description: Plots train and validation accuracy as training sample size increases for the pseudo-supervised cluster classifier.
sklearn:LearningCurveDisplay.interpretation: Converging curves imply stable cluster separability. Large gaps suggest overfitting to cluster labels.
sklearn:LearningCurveDisplay.ecci_context: Indicates whether cluster assignments are robust across more events or sensitive to sample size.
sklearn:LearningCurveDisplay.when_to_use: Use when validating stability of cluster labeling or deciding if more data improves separation.

sklearn:ValidationCurveDisplay.name: Validation Curve (Sklearn)
sklearn:ValidationCurveDisplay.description: Plots train and validation accuracy as a classifier hyperparameter varies for pseudo-label modeling.
sklearn:ValidationCurveDisplay.interpretation: Find the parameter region where validation accuracy peaks without a large train-test gap.
sklearn:ValidationCurveDisplay.ecci_context: Use to tune the surrogate classifier that explains clusters, not the KMeans model itself.
sklearn:ValidationCurveDisplay.when_to_use: Use when you want a stable surrogate model for explaining clusters.

FreqDistVisualizer.name: Frequency Distribution Visualizer
FreqDistVisualizer.description: Bar chart showing the most frequent terms in the text corpus (search queries). Displays term frequency distribution with optional filtering.
FreqDistVisualizer.interpretation: Tall bars indicate common search terms. Long tail shows rare terms. The distribution shape (Zipfian) reveals vocabulary diversity.
FreqDistVisualizer.ecci_context: Reveals **what customers search for most**. Top terms inform product placement, SEO strategy, and inventory decisions. Rare terms might indicate unmet needs or niche markets.
FreqDistVisualizer.when_to_use: Use to understand search query patterns before building text-based features. Essential for search optimization and product discovery.
FreqDistVisualizer.parameters: `n`: Number of top terms to show, `orient`: Horizontal or vertical bars, `stopwords`: Terms to exclude

TSNEVisualizer.name: t-SNE Text Visualizer
TSNEVisualizer.description: t-SNE projection of text documents (search queries) showing semantic similarity. Documents close together have similar word usage patterns.
TSNEVisualizer.interpretation: Clusters indicate groups of semantically similar search queries. Isolated points are unique queries. Spread indicates vocabulary diversity.
TSNEVisualizer.ecci_context: Reveals **search intent clusters**: product searches, deal hunting, comparison shopping. Helps understand how customers naturally group their search behavior.
TSNEVisualizer.when_to_use: Use for exploring text data structure when you suspect natural groupings in search queries. Computationally expensive.
TSNEVisualizer.parameters: `perplexity`: Balance of local vs global structure, `n_iter`: Optimization iterations

UMAPVisualizer.name: UMAP Text Visualizer
UMAPVisualizer.description: UMAP projection of text documents showing semantic similarity. Faster than t-SNE and often preserves more global structure.
UMAPVisualizer.interpretation: Similar to t-SNE but with better preservation of global relationships. Clusters represent query groups, distances between clusters are more meaningful.
UMAPVisualizer.ecci_context: Like t-SNE but faster and better at showing relationships between query clusters. Use when you want to understand both local patterns and overall search landscape.
UMAPVisualizer.when_to_use: Use as a faster alternative to t-SNE, especially for larger text corpora. Better when global structure matters.
UMAPVisualizer.parameters: `n_neighbors`: Local neighborhood size, `min_dist`: Minimum distance between points, `metric`: Distance metric

DispersionPlot.name: Dispersion Plot
DispersionPlot.description: Shows where specific words appear across documents. Each row is a word, each column represents document position, dots show occurrences.
DispersionPlot.interpretation: Evenly dispersed words appear throughout the corpus. Clustered dots indicate words concentrated in specific documents/periods.
DispersionPlot.ecci_context: Track how search terms evolve over time or customer sessions. Seasonal terms (holiday, sale) should cluster; evergreen terms should disperse evenly.
DispersionPlot.when_to_use: Use to understand temporal or positional patterns in search queries. Good for detecting seasonal trends or campaign effects.
DispersionPlot.parameters: `words`: Specific words to track, `ignore_case`: Case-insensitive matching

WordCorrelationPlot.name: Word Correlation Plot
WordCorrelationPlot.description: Heatmap showing pairwise correlation between words based on co-occurrence. Reveals which words tend to appear together in search queries.
WordCorrelationPlot.interpretation: High positive correlation = words often appear together. Negative correlation = words rarely co-occur. Zero = independent usage.
WordCorrelationPlot.ecci_context: Discovers **common search patterns**: 'cheap + phone', 'gift + box'. Informs bundling opportunities, autocomplete suggestions, and related product recommendations.
WordCorrelationPlot.when_to_use: Use to discover word associations and common phrase patterns. Valuable for search UX improvement and product bundling.
WordCorrelationPlot.parameters: `terms`: Words to analyze, `method`: Correlation method (pearson, spearman)

PosTagVisualizer.name: Part-of-Speech Tag Visualizer
PosTagVisualizer.description: Bar chart showing the distribution of part-of-speech tags (nouns, verbs, adjectives, etc.) in the text corpus.
PosTagVisualizer.interpretation: High noun frequency = specific product searches. High adjective frequency = attribute-focused searches (cheap, best, red). Verbs might indicate intent (buy, compare).
PosTagVisualizer.ecci_context: Reveals **search intent structure**: Noun-heavy = product-focused, Adjective-heavy = quality-conscious customers, Verb-heavy = action-oriented searches.
PosTagVisualizer.when_to_use: Use to understand the linguistic structure of search queries. Informs query processing and intent classification strategies.
PosTagVisualizer.parameters: `tags`: Specific POS tags to include, `normalize`: Show percentages vs counts
